channel.title: Auxy Tips and Tricks from the "Experienced"
channel.description:
Hey guys, I created this topic because I want artists and musicians that are starting out in Auxy, or just use Auxy to make music but haven't really put out a track they feel like they put their best effort into, to gain valuable feedback from members of the community that have climbed this mountain already. In this thread anyone can ask questions they have regarding Auxy and the production/effort involved into making a great track. I invite everyone who can share knowledge but especially @IAATOE, @Southborne, @xavior, @crystldawnmusic, @anon41616463, @aUstin_Haga, @stereofield, @NEWNAMES, and @blackocean, to come share some valuable feedback that anyone can use to improve their Auxy tracks as well as answer questions that the community has. I hope that this helps everyone become a better musician!
EDIT: Please don't be discouraged if your name isn't on this list above ^^^ There are a ton more of experienced producers out there and I just mentioned a few. :smile:

item.title: Auxy Tips and Tricks from the "Experienced"
item.dc:creator: Aqzi
item.description:
welp- I’ve been using Auxy for 3 years now so I guess I qualify here; use an instrument because it’s good, not because it’s not from the new sound pack Vintage Retro:tm:

Read full topic

item.title: Auxy Tips and Tricks from the "Experienced"
item.dc:creator: Aadam
item.description:
This thread doesn’t deserve to die again.

Anyways, a good I have (that I’ve seen from the “Experienced”) is to put a clap one precision note before your kicksnare, and make it’s offset be a bit forward so it hits a millisecond before.

Read full topic

item.title: Auxy Tips and Tricks from the "Experienced"
item.dc:creator: Toveii
item.description:
Okay here’s a tip from me. Take advantage of the gain and shelf mechanics in Volume. Idk if it’s just me, but I from what I’ve seen, it’s not used as much. Probably because of confusion. If you’re not sure how to use it, this is how I do it in my ambient/house tracks. Anyways, say here for example that you have a loop of a 4 chord with two different layered saws (could also be pads or piano). So then you have a lead on top of those saws. The saws are too much in the high frequencies, which causes your lead to be muffled. Well, good thing we can fix it. Go to the high and shelf mechanics in Volume of the saw instruments. The only thing you will move is the “High Gain”. So now, you want to move the High Gain bar to the left at most anywhere from -4.0dB to 0dB. Any lower than that will filter out the saw which causes to lose its brightness. Okay great! You’ve just cut off unwanted frequencies for the saws, and the lead has popped out more. Now, we will also change the dB High Gain for your lead. So, go to your volume lead instrument. Of course, since a lead is always in the high frequencies, you need to move the High Gain bar to the right anywhere from 6.0dB to 12.0dB. Now you’ve just cut off low frequencies for the lead. I can hear the mixing in your project is off the charts right now. Hopefully my explanation was specific and understandable lol. That’s all I have for now. LAYER YOUR SNARES AND LEADS.

Read full topic
item.source: Auxy Tips and Tricks from the "Experienced"

item.title: Auxy Tips and Tricks from the "Experienced"
item.dc:creator: NotMiles
item.description:
A trick I’ve been using since the pianos and pitch automation came out: take whatever loop you have and raise it an octave in the note editor. Then drop it down to its original octave with a pitch automation (nothing fancy, literally just a straight line). Boom, now the piano has a slightly washed out tone. I actually do this with the majority of instruments to bring out a darker tone. (Doesn’t work well with all of the instruments however.) I’ve literally stopped using Silk without doing this to it.

Read full topic
item.source: Auxy Tips and Tricks from the "Experienced"
